Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Studies of Antibiotics and Their Degradates in the Environment
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Analytical and Surface Chemistry Program in the Chemistry Division, Professors Diana Aga, Jochen Autschbach, and Frank Bright of the University at Buffalo are developing stable and highly selective molecularly imprinted xerogel sorbents for clean-up and pre-concentration of environmental samples for analysis. Synthesis and selection of sorbents with high selectivity and affinity is based on a high-throughput combinatorial production and screening approach, augmented by ab-initio and semiempirical quantum chemical computations. The work includes fundamental studies of the environmental fate of residues of pharmaceutical contaminants in soil using a combination of mass spectrometric techniques and 14C-labeled tracers. Results from this research will improve analytical capabilities for accurately identifying and quantifying unknown antibiotic degradates in the environment.

Results from these studies will provide decision makers with information to accurately assess and, if necessary, mitigate aquatic and human exposure to other pharmaceutical contaminants. Further, this project will provide unique research experiences to graduate and undergraduate students because they will be exposed to various aspects of quantitative and qualitative analysis, theoretical chemistry, and issues in environmental chemistry, government regulations, and agricultural sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The presence of trace concentrations of pharmaceutical residues in water and soil is a critical environmental issue that emerged recently following research reports demonstrating deleterious ecotoxicological effects of pharmaceutical contaminants in the environment. In particular, antibiotic contamination of soil, surface water, and groundwater have raised public concern due to the increased emergence and distribution of antibiotic resistance in bacteria that are exposed constantly to low levels of antibiotics. Residues of human and veterinary pharmaceuticals are introduced into the environment via a number of pathways, but primarily from discharges of wastewater treatment plants or land application of sewage sludge and animal manure. The lack of information on the degradation and fate of antibiotics at environmentally relevant concentrations is largely due to analytical difficulties encountered in detecting trace levels of unknown degradates in complex matrices such as soil and manure.

The overall goal of this research is to advance fundamental knowledge about the environmental fate and transport of pharmaceutical contaminants by improving the sample preparation strategies. Detection and identification of unknown antibiotic degradates in soil is currently very challenging using traditional solid-phase extraction (SPE) and LC/MS (liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry) methods. Liquid chromatography coupled to mass spectrometry (LC/MS) has become a widely used tool in the analysis of polar pollutants such as antibiotics. However, LC/MS is vulnerable to matrix interferences resulting in poor detectability of analytes at trace levels and in variable ionization efficiencies which compromises accuracy and precision of analysis. To achieve a comprehensive risk assessment of antibiotics it is clear that there is a need for more selective sample preparation strategies that will allow the detection of antibiotics and their degradation products in complex environmental matrices. This study involved the development of class-selective Molecularly Imprinted Xerogels (MIXs) as sorbents for SPE to isolate parent antibiotics and closely related degradates.  In addition, a highly sensitive LC/MS method that can simultaneously detect several antibiotics in one method was developed for the fast analysis of organic contaminants in water. The proposed research focuses on tetracyclines (TCs) and sulfonamides (SAs), two of the most widely used classes of antibiotics in the animal industry.

The overall goal of this research is to determine the identities and leaching potential of degradation products of two widely used veterinary antibiotics, chlortetracycline (tetracycline class) and sulfamethazine (sulfonamide class) in soil. The specific objectives are:

  1. Develop highly stable, class-selective molecularly imprinted xerogels (MIXs) as sorbents for isolating residues of antibiotics and their degradates in soil
  2. Determine the persistence of TCs and SAs in soil and identify structurally-related degradates isolated by MIXs using mass spectrometric techniques
  3. Evaluate the soil mobility of the antibiotic degradates relative to the parent antibiotics

We showed that by using theoretical calculations, the synthesis of MIXs can be guided by focusing on template molecules that have strong interactions with MIXs.
